entry.title: LeetCode 240. Search a 2D Matrix II
entry.content:
Write an efficient algorithm that searches for a value in an m x n matrix. This matrix has the following properties:

  • Integers in each row are sorted in ascending from left to right.
  • Integers in each column are sorted in ascending from top to bottom.

entry.title: LeetCode 238. Product of Array Except Self
entry.content:
Given an array nums of n integers where n > 1, return an array output such that output[i] is equal to the product of all the elements of nums except nums[i].

Example:

Constraint: It's guaranteed that the product of the elements of any prefix or suffix of the array (including the whole array) fits in a 32 bit integer.

Note: Please solve it without division and in O(n).

Follow up: Could you solve it with constant space complexity? (The output array does not count as extra space for the purpose of space complexity analysis.)

The thought is :

divide into two parts the left part and the right part

i1234
Left1(default)11 * 21 * 2 * 3
Right2 * 3 * 43 * 441(default)
Product=left*right241286

Slightly space improved version :

entry.title: LeetCode 309. Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock with Cooldown
entry.content:
Say you have an array for which the ith element is the price of a given stock on day i.

Design an algorithm to find the maximum profit. You may complete as many transactions as you like (ie, buy one and sell one share of the stock multiple times) with the following restrictions:

  • You may not engage in multiple transactions at the same time (ie, you must sell the stock before you buy again).
  • After you sell your stock, you cannot buy stock on next day. (ie, cooldown 1 day)

Example:

entry.title: LeetCode 146. LRU Cache
entry.content:
Design and implement a data structure for Least Recently Used (LRU) cache. It should support the following operations: get and put.

get(key) - Get the value (will always be positive) of the key if the key exists in the cache, otherwise return -1.
put(key, value) - Set or insert the value if the key is not already present. When the cache reached its capacity, it should invalidate the least recently used item before inserting a new item.

The cache is initialized with a positive capacity.

Follow up:
Could you do both operations in O(1) time complexity?

Example:

Use a cache map to store all the elements

entry.title: LeetCode 239. Sliding Window Maximum
entry.content:
Given an array nums, there is a sliding window of size k which is moving from the very left of the array to the very right. You can only see the k numbers in the window. Each time the sliding window moves right by one position. Return the max sliding window.

Follow up:
Could you solve it in linear time?

Example:

Constraints:

  • 1 <= nums.length <= 10^5
  • -10^4 <= nums[i] <= 10^4
  • 1 <= k <= nums.length

entry.title: Google校园空中宣讲会笔记：简历如何准备
entry.content:
HR和面试官关于简历的部分

最好是中英双语版本的简历

通过KS后的面试流程

面试官说严肃正式的面试不会有brain teaser 然后那些个语言其实也没啥 自己拿自己最熟悉的就行 数据结构和算法不会要求全部掌握的 不会是ACM难度 课本难度 如果是别的专业的话没关系 会考虑到专业背景的 反正进去是大类SDE让你干啥你干啥…… 所以语言和技术栈不那么重要

brute force 也要说出来

看到你进步更重要哈 毕竟好不容易面一个 都是想抓住你的闪光点的
entry.summary:
HR和面试官关于简历的部分

最好是中英双语版本的简历

entry.title: JavaScript : a classic interview question
entry.content:
While here are the answers ( yeah I run them in the browser )

Well , it has been defined as Foo.getName = function () { alert (2);};

Surprise it is NOT 5 !

Remainder :

Hoisting is JavaScript's default behavior of moving declarations to the top.

JavaScript only hoists declarations, not initializations.

Still hosting problem :

This is about the operator precedence rule of JavaScript

20 new (with argument list) > new (without argument list)

So this is what actually happens :

Here getName() is a constructor

(new Foo()).getName()

And the constructor has a return value this

So it equals to this.getName()

Because there is no getName property in Foo for a new instance so JS will look into the prototype

Foo.prototype.getName = function () { alert (3);}; => alert 3

Same thing with the opertator precedence rule

new (new (Foo().getName()))

entry.title: LeetCode N-Queens
entry.content:
The n-queens puzzle is the problem of placing n queens on an n×n chessboard such that no two queens attack each other.

Given an integer n, return all distinct solutions to the n-queens puzzle.

Each solution contains a distinct board configuration of the n-queens' placement, where 'Q' and '.' both indicate a queen and an empty space respectively.

Example:

Prerequisite:

The some() method tests whether at least one element in the array passes the test implemented by the provided function. It returns a Boolean value.

entry.title: Java: why strings cannot be altered
entry.content:
Let’s inspect the source code :

Because it is defined as final

And it is implemented by byte

Let’s dissect the byte thing :

byte is a primitive data type , 1 byte , and stores whole numbers from -128 to 127

Other params of String :

String is born with hash params !

Also let’s look at the Integer thing

When -128~127 ,

So Integer a = 100 and Integer b = 100 is stored at the same place. If you run System.out.print(a==b) you will get a true.
